message_1:
Solve the following relevance logic problem:

There are 6 clues in a crime scene investigation. Each clue is either relevant or irrelevant to solving the case. If exactly 4 clues are relevant to the case and there are no irrelevant clues present, how many ways can the relevant clues be selected?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where C(n, k) represents the number of combinations of selecting k items from a set of n items, n! is the factorial of n, and k! is the factorial of k.

In this case, there are 6 clues (n = 6) and we want to select 4 relevant clues (k = 4). So, we can plug these values into the formula:

C(6, 4) = 6! / (4!(6-4)!)

C(6, 4) = 6! / (4!2!)

C(6, 4) = (6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((4 × 3 × 2 × 1)(2 × 1))

C(6, 4) = (720) / (24 × 2)

C(6, 4) = 720 / 48

C(6, 4) = 15

So, there are 15 different ways to select the 4 relevant clues from the 6 clues in the crime scene investigation.
